November 12, 1940 This collection contains a 1940 report: Report on Investigations Concerning the Future Development of the School of Architecture and Allied Arts by a Committee of Faculty of the School. Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.

Arrangement
The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received.

Scope and Contents
This collection contains a 1940 report: Report on Investigations Concerning the Future Development of the School of Architecture and Allied Arts by a Committee of Faculty of the School. This report was created to survey the value of the School of Architecture and Allied Arts to New York University and the community.
Conditions Governing Use
This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).
Historical Note
The School of Architecture and Allied Arts was established as a department of architecture in 1926 under the leadership of architect E. Raymond Bossange. Two years later, the University established a College of Fine Arts (which the department of architecture was a part of) and elevated Bossange to its deanship in 1930. In 1935, the College was renamed the School of Architecture and Allied Arts. The School was closed in 1941.
Source:
"N.Y.U. Will Close Architects' School," New York Times, May 18, 1941 (accessed February 9, 2023).
